div.head: KHEDIVIAL MAIL LINE.
div.p: Express Steamers leave Alexandria every Wednesday at 4 p.m. for PIRAEUS, SMYRNA, MITYLENE, and CONSTANTINOPLE, in connection with Orient Express train-de-luxe for Vienna, Paris, and London.

Fast steamers leave Alexandria every Saturday at 6 p.m., and Port Said every Sunday at 6 p.m., for JAFFA (for Jerusalem), CAIFFA (for Nazareth), BEYROUT (for Damascus), TRIPOLI, ALEXANDRETTA, MESSINA, continuing in alternate weeks to LARNACA and LIMASSOL (Cyprus).

Steamers leave Suez fortnightly on Wednesday at 6 p.m. for JEDDAH, SUAKIN, MASSOWAH, HODBIDAH, and ADEN ; and in the intervening weeks for PORT SUDAN and SUAKIN direct. Calls will be made at TOR (for Mount Sinai) as required.
N.B.—Deck chairs provided for the use of passengers, excellent cuisine and table wine free.
Steamer plans may be seen and passages booked at the Company’s Agencies at Alexandria, Cairo, Port Said, and Suez, or at THOS. COOK & SON or other Tourist Agency.

div.head: THE NATIONAL HOTEL, Cairo
div.p: One of the finest and most up-to-date Hotels in the Metropolis. Situated in Sharia Soliman Pasha, the very centre of the healthiest and most fashionable quarter. Stands in its own grounds with garden and lawn tennis grounds at back. Over 350 rooms and 5 saloons. Magnificent salle à manger. Handsome covered promenade verandah, 80 yards long. Highest class cuisine, electric light throughout, and lifts. English comforts. Rooms and apartments at prices to suit everyone. For further particulars apply to GENERAL MANAGER, Cairo.

div.p: Helouan, near Cairo.

Formerly the favourite Residence of H.H. the Khedive. Perfect Sanitation.–Purest Desert air. Electric Light. Hot and old baths attached to most rooms. A few days ago we published a review of the interesting article on the palms of Egypt, which has been contributed to the Bulletin of the Alexandria Horticultural Society by M. A d’Abaza The Bulletin contains two other very valuable contributions, of which “Some Hints on Rose-growing in Egypt” is a practical guide to the cultivation of the queen of flowers by one who is the acknowledged British “facile princeps” of the art in this country — the Anglo-Egyptian Dean Hole Every word, therefore, from him on this subject is sure to be read with the deepest attention. Dr. Keat- inge who, some years ago, gave Alexandrians a tiuch appreciated lecture on rose growing,
modestly deprecates any idea of a claim on his part to originality in his ‘hints,” most of which he assures us have been culled from the
“Boot of the Rose” (by the late Rev. A.

Foster Melliar) of which he strongly advises the purchase. The sixteen pages of his paper contain valuable hints on every branch of Egyptian rose cultivation, ending with a most useful list of 18 hybrid roses, 29 tea roses and 12 climbing varieties, which Dr Keatinge's personal experience has proved will do, Well in this country.

The last 18 pages of the Bulletin consist of “Leaves from a Note Book” by Judge San­ders, the vice-president of the committee of the A. H. S., whose reputation as a practical horti­culturist and the successful organizer of our Alexandria flower-shows, from their commence­ment, has long been established. The “Leaves” contain a large amount of interesting histo­rical information on the subject of Egyptian cultivated plants, from various sources, com- mencing with a resume of what is known con- cerning the “Papyrus,” its gradual extinction, and reintroduction of late years. The “Jaca- randa,” mentioned as one of the trees intro­duced under Mehemet Ali (1803-1847), is igno­red by Delchevalerie in his “Etudes Egyptien- nes” (l870) describing all the gardens of Cairo and Alexandria except the one at Alexandria in which the solitary Jacaranda in Egypt existed; nor did he include it in the list of seeds and flowers of all the ornamental trees in Egypt shewn by him at the Vienna Interna­tional exhibition in 1873.

The above garden, now belonging to the Jesuit College, but formerly known as Beit Thurburn from its proprietor 80 years ago, was rented by General Sir E. Stanton when Consul General (1866-1876), and the Jacaranda may have been planted during his tenure. It was still a very fine tree in 1885, but has since disappeared, being a rapid grower but very short-lived ; Delchevalerie mentions the bee for the first time in his “Apercu General,” written for the “Societe d’acclimatation de France” (1881), as flowering and fruiting well in “le jardin de Torborn a Alexandrie” whence it had, by that time, spread over the Delta and been some years in the gardens of Ghizeh, Ghezireh and the Ezbekieh in Cairo The “Jacaranda mimosifolia” (J. Ovalifolia) was introduced to British cultivation from Brazil in 1818 as a stove plant.

It is curious that the English name “potato” for the “Solanum tuberosum,” brought by Thomas Harriot (1560-1621), the mathema­tical tutor of Sir W. Raleigh, from Virginia in 1585 (where it seems to have been imported from S. America), should be a corruption of the American name for the “Sweet Potato” (Batatas edulis), a plant of the “convolvulus” family said by von Humboldt to have been brought to Spain by Christopher Columbus 92 years before Virginia was christened ; and again, in 1519, when Pigafetta introduced it from Brazil ; the Batatas was cultivated in Eng and long before the common potato, and the two plants, of such diverse botanical classification, were frequently confounded in contemporary accounts. The potato has long been known in Spanish S. America as “Papas” and the sweet potato as “Batatas.”

The view of our great lexicographer, cited by Judge Sandars, that “if he was a rich man he would propagate all kinds of trees that grow in the open air,” rather than such as require the shelter of glass, is one that we cordially endorse, especially as applied to the climate of Egypt, for which we have such vast store of beautiful flowering shrubs and herbaceous perennials to draw upon, from similar latitudes in both hemispheres, as com­pared with the possibilities of acclimatisation in Great Britain. We earnestly hope that, under its new financial conditions, the A.H.S. will not confine its efforts entirely to the utilitarian side of horticulture, and will soon gladden our eyes with the sight of some ornamental novelties; for beautiful as our

Flamboyants, Jacarandas, Tecomas, Poinset- tias, and Oleanders are in our Alexandria gardens, we are tired of seeing the same trees, shrubs and creepers in all of them, and long for some of the many equally hardy flowering and foliage beauties, only waiting to be transferred from their native subtro­pical homes in China, Japan, North and South America, the East and West Indies, Australia, and South Africa to the cosmo­politan land of Egypt.
It is understood that an Irish Devolution

Bill will be presented as a provisional experi­ment and the arrangements for the constitu­tion of the Irish Council will be left open for enlargement for 10 years’ time. It is expected that the lrish Commoners will be ipso facto members of the new Council. The success of the experiment will depend upon the Council's disposal of the money scorning from savings under the Imperial administration. (Reuter}

hero last night. Sir G Farrar declared that the Progressives were fighting for God and the King against oligarchy and the autocracy, and they must work for the establishment of a British South Africa and to eliminate Down ing Street influence. (Reuter)

div.p: DELTA LAND CO. LTD.
IMPORTANT DECISIONS.

We are authorised by the Egyptian Delta Land and Investment Company to state that a meeting of the directors held on Saturday confirmed the resolution arrived at by the Delta Light Railway Company’s Board to re-affiliate the two companies on the original terms on which the Delta Land Company was formed. This decision must, of course, be confirmed by
general meeting of the shareholders.

Farther, the London Board of the Delta Land Company having carefully considered the question as to whether the company’s business could be administered from London or Egypt, ate convinced that in the best interests of the shareholders the administration should be in Egypt and, as a very large majority of the shareholders are resident in Egypt, their convenience would be better studied if general meetings were held in Egypt. Taking these matters into consideration the London Board has generously come to the conclusion that they would best serve the interests of the shareholders by resigning. They have therefore elected the following gentlemen to replace them, viz.. Mr. P. W. Carver of Alexandria, Maurice Cattaui Bey of Cairo,Capt. A. Adams, R E , general manager of the Egyptian Delta Light Railways. These three gentlemen, together with Baron Jacques de Menasce and Mr. J. W Williamson, will form the new board of the Delta Land Co. and it will be farther strengthened by the addition of a mem-her of the firm of Messrs. Snares of Cairo as soon as certain negotiations now pending be-tween the company and Messrs. Snares are completed.

We are pleased to hear that the new Board of the Delta Land Co. have made very strong representations to Sir Auckland Colvin, K C S.I, K.C.M.G., C.I.E, to remain honorary president of the company. Sir Auckland has not yet definitely accepted but we feel confident we are voicing the wishes of the shareholders in begging of him to give a favourable answer to this request, for the able and generous manner in which he has brought to an amicable solution the outstanding differences between the London and local Boards of the company has endeared him to the shareholders, who feel that with Sir Auckland Colvin as honorary president of their company they would not be severing their connection with him,
THE KHEDIVE’S RETURN.
The Khedive is expected to arrive at Mon-t>zah to-morrow on his return from the Siwa Oasis. His Highness will proceed to Cairo on Wednesday evening.
H.H. the Khedivah came down to Alexandria on 8atnrday from Cairo in order to meet the Khedive on his arrival from the desert.
DEATH OF KHEDIVIAL PRINCE.
We regret to announce the death of Prince Ahmed Kamel Pasha, ancle of the Khedive, which took place at Cairo on Saturday at midnight. The funeral took place yesterday afternoon.
The late Prince, it is said, left an estate of the value of over L.E. 3,000,000. This has been bequeathed to his son Prince Youssef.
TO-DAY’S PROSPECTUSES.

We beg to draw the attention of our readers to the three interesting prospectuses which we publish in another part of to day’s issue. “Le-vico Limited” is the conversion of the well-known and respected Alexandrian firm of Messrs V. Levi and Company into an English limited liability company. "La Barque d’Es-compte et de Reports” is a new bank, which will no doubt attract the serious attention of the investing public. The Nile Transport Company will fill a need in catering for the ever increasing development of Nilotic navi-gation.
Another issue, which we announce to day, is that of the Express Nile Steamers Limited. The fall details of this new issue will be found in the next paragraph.

LOCAL AND GENERAL.
ASSOUAN DAM.
ANTIQUARIANS ALARMED.
PROTEST TO LORD CROMER.

The antiquarians are in a great state of excitement on the subject of the heightening of the Assouan Dam and intend to make as much fuss as they did when the idea of making the dam was first mooted. At the last meeting of the Society of Antiquaries the following resolution was unanimously adopted, and a copy of it directed to be sent to Lord Cromer: "The Society of Antiquaries of London has heard with tome surprise that a proposal is seriously entertained by the Egyptian Government to raise the level of the Nile dam at Assouan to the height originally proposed. The Society would point out that it is informed that such an alteration would, at high Nile, submerge the temples at Philae, and would result also in the flooding of a large area in Nubia undoubtedly containing many interesting sites. The Society feels bound to enter a protest against any scheme that would involve such a wholesale destruction of archaeological remains unless it be clearly demonstrated that the scheme is an absolute necessity for the well being of Egypt, and that the same benefits cannot be obtained in any other way. The Society feels the greater confidence in making the protest to the Egyptian Government in view of the important and costly works of conservation that have already been carried out at Phi’®.”

The prime mover in this agitation is Mr. Somers Clarke. This gentleman sent a letter to the Society of Antiquaries calling attention to a proposal to raise the dam at Assouan to the level originally suggested, despite the undertaking given in 1894 that it should not be carried higher than at present. Mr. Clarke recalled the disastrons effect such raising would entail both as regards the temples at Philae, and a large part of Nubia, which would be hopelessly drowned, and suggested that the Society should take action in the matter.
SAVOY DANCE.
OPERA IN CAIRO.
KHEDIVIAL THEATRE.
Alexandria’s New Hotel.
The inauguration of the Savoy Palace Hotel in Rosetta-avenue will take place on Saturday, 23rd inst., when a grand reception will be held in the afternoon.
Savoy Bail.
We may remind our readers that the 8avoy fancy dress ball takes place on Tuesday next. Persons not wearing a fancy dress will have to pay a fine of P.T. 40 for charity.
Mona House Hotel.
The great fancy dress ball at Mena House takes place on Wednesday next at 9.30 p.m. Guests not wearing fancy dress will pay a fine of P.T. 20, the proceeds of which will go to charity.
Plague at Jeddah.

The Delegate of the Quarantine Board in the Hedjiz telegraphs that five deaths from plague took place on the 15th inst. at Jeddah. The deaths up to date number 50. The general state of health is unsatisfactory.
The Khedivial Ball.

Over two thousand invitations have been issued for the Khedivial Ball which is to be held at Abdeen Palace on the 28th inst., and further invitations are being issued. This year’s ball is expected to eclipse any that has ever bean held at Abdesn Palace.
Societe Internationale des Employee.”

A benefit performance will be given at the Zizinia Theatre on Wednesday next, 20th just., on behalf of the “Societe Internationale des Employes d’Alexandria,” when “La Dannazione di Faust” will be given. Almost all the seats have been taken for the occasion.
M. Zervudachi’s Cold Mine

Mr. George Zervudachi’, of Alexandris, has purchased an Abyssinian gold mine from a Russian. On Saturday last an expedition left Alexandria for Abyssinia consisting of the engineering expert, M. Carafan, two French mining experts, and a number of workmen, in order to work the mine.
Reception for Americans.

Mr. Iddings the American Diplomatic Agent and Consul General, and Mrs. Iddings will be “at home” at the Agency. No. 5, Scha warbi Pasha street Cairo, on Friday next, 22nd inst., Washington's birthday, and will be glad to receive any of their compatriots who are in Cairo on that day, and who may do them the honour to call between 4 and 6 o'clock.

STEAMER MOVEMENTS.
The Moss liner Philae arrived this morning from Glasgow, via Gibraltar and Malta, with general cargo.
The S.S. Bulgarian (Westcott and Laurence Line) left Malta on Saturday morning, and i due here next Wednesday from Antwerp and London.

Saturday evening was so balmy and warm that the hall doors of the Savoy were opened wide and the dancers took fall advantage of the verandah between the dances, which were not finished till nearly half past one. The warmth of the ball room was quite ex-cessive at times, and many people preferred to take their pleasure gently, though there were a few who clamoured for more even after the orchestra had left.

There were a good many strangers present on Saturday, and at one end of the room there was a bevy of some of the most beautiful frocks that have been seen this season. One especially attracted the notice of everyone : it was in white cut en princesse and had wide glittering lines of silver falling from the host to the hem, where there was a border of delicately painted roses. The same painted roses mingled with silver formed the sleeves and the decolletage, lines of thin filmy black outlining the fulness and being gathered into a big bow high at the back. Close by the wearer of this lovely frock was another in a dull deep shade of heliotrope with broad bands of dull silver lace on the skirt and corsage, the trimming the latter being continued over the shoulders and in a deep square across the back.

Lord and Lady Lanesborough were present, and Lady Newborough, who looked magnificent in a grey brocade, the bodice spark-ling with jewels. The Countess of Hollnstein was also most handsomely attired and wore beautiful jewels. Lord and Lady Vivian were here, and Col. El Lewa and Mrs. Watson were also among the dancers, the latter wearing a handsome pink silk dress trimmed with gar-lauds of double stitched ruchings. Miss Blyth was with Capt. and Mrs. Rome ; and Mrs. and Miss Crofton were with Mrs. and Miss Carey and Miss Fox: Miss Crofton in blue embroidered with roses, Miss Carey wearing a lovely frock of white chiffon em- broidered with marguerites and bordered with doll green panne, while the latter was in diamentee white. Mrs. Armstrong was in very handsome gown of white moire en-trusted with heavy lace and bordered with large pompadour roses. Mrs. Mende’s hand-some dress of bine was also adorned with pink roses, and one of her near neighbours had lovely panels of painted roses on her dress. Mrs. Stout was in a very pretty frock of fine lace, and Miss McKellar had on a delightful frock of black net trimmed with bands of velvet and lace and showing pointed vest and sleeves of white lace. Mrs Park Lyle was wearing a lovely bandeau o diamonds and turquoise across her hair, herf dress of soft satin bearing insertions of lace or net covered with ruchings and bands of satin.

Others present were Major and Mrs. Wynne, Miss Blythe, Mrs. and Miss Leverich, Mr. and Mrs. Packet, the Messrs and Miss de Bilinski, Mr. and Miss Pooley, Miss Tuck, Mr. and M'S. Scott-Dalgleish, Misses de Vahl, Mrs. and Miss Marron, Miss Nungovich, Mr. and Miss Allan Joseph, Miss Fearon, Miss Shaw, Mrs. and Miss de Wahn.
‘ SAMSON ET DALILA.”

What a contrast to last year's excellent performance ! It serves us right for grambling then. Mme. Chaix Bonheursaved the 2nd act by good acting and scientific use of a rather distasteful voice. M. Moisson was fair but odourless ; M. Mezy voluminous and inaccu-rate. The flower chorus was of course hopeless and—here Mme. Chaix Bonheur and M. Mezy should have done better. The fine fugal duet and chorus at the end was badly sang. She was too slow and he too fast. The ballet pleased a good many people : certainly Mile. Deliny looked pretty and danced gracefully ; but the chief attraction was the tune thereof ; after all, it is singularly like the ‘ danse au ventre.” M. Chappelon as the old Israelite was quite good, and sang correctly.
“LOUISE.”

A rather colourless performance except for the workroom scene, and the last act of all. Both these were well enough done : the “Butte. Montmartre” scene needed far more singing than M. Fontaine and Mile. Charpentier could give.The orchestra was rather tame throughout. After all, “Louise” is a disappointing opera. It has really original effects: the daybreak scene at Montmartre, the workroom, and the duet at Julien's house, followed by the entry of the masqueraders, are charming in conception and in execution. Poor M. Monteux ! really was amusing as the pape des fous, not the audience will only laugh at his voice every time he tries to sing. His acting is not so bad ; — this by the way. The scenes which might have been great are also charming—but no more. The duet, and the whole finale, that stirring “Paris m’appelle”—what an opportunity for a really great composer who could have shown the soul of it all, love, revolt, convention, and the call of that great city tearing that convention to pieces, exacting worship and suffering of its sons and daughters !
ABBAS THEATRE.
“ERNaNI.”

The fine old filibustering sentiment of “Ernani” seemed to please the performers, and more especially Sig. Arrighetti, who was in splendid form. Sig. Lucenti was, as ever, delightful all through. i g. Battani is most disappointing this year to many of those who delighted in him during the summer: but I confess I cannot agree with them altogether. He has not the exquisite delicacy which made certain songs so memorable, but it seems to me that his voice is far fuller and more developed, especially in the low notes. It may be simply the bad weather, or it may be that his voice is (if such things do happen ) in a state of transition from lyric to strong tenor. Bat the fact remains that he, Lucenti, and Arrighetti hold their own against the music and that the conductor has not to be always thinking whether a big orchestral effect will drown his voice. It is a pity his acting is so poor. His manipulation of the dagger (and, indeed, all the death scene) was rather absurd.
“FEDORA.”

“Fedora” halted at first, but improved rapidly, and, taken altogether, was a fine performance. Sig. Orbellini was distinctly ex-cellent, as was Sig. Mastropasque, who acted delightfully. Sig. Tschierdo sang the part of Loris really well. Sig. de Padova is a moat useful if rather light baritone. The “Chopin” scene was better done than is usually the case ; the pianist is not often a success, but he certainly was quite good in this case. Sig. Campanini is certainly a fine conductor, he knows his music thoroughly, and has a thorough grasp of orchestra, chorus, and principals as well. They all hive to do their ntmost for him ; it was absolutely fascinating at times to watch his "baron” and his hands and to notice how instantaneous was the response. It seemed impossible for his “personnel’’ to go wrong. We saw this in “Mefis-tofele” and “Faust,” and it was most marked in “Fedora.” It is the height of pleasure to see such thorough mastery and knowledge combined.
PERSONAL AND SOCIAL.
Oar Assouan Correspondent telegraphs that Lord and Lady Cromer arrived there by steamer on Saturday evening and left again this morning. No receptions were held.
The family of the late Simon Arbib Bey beg to thank all their friends and acquaintances for the numerous tokens of sympathy which they have received in consequence of their recent bereavement.
Mrs. J. Hubbalday Burton has been safely delivered of a son. Mother and child are both doing well.

cell.p: H. M. SALMONY, Esq , Wamford Court, London, E.C.
Thia Company has been formed for the purposes specified in the Memorandum of
(1) To acquire and take over the business now carried on by Messrs. V. Levi & Co. of
(2) To effect the purchase and sale of stocks and shares on the local and continental
bourses and the London Stock Exchange for their own account and for the account of-third
To undertake the purchase and sale of cotton, cotton seed and other produce on the
local and continental bourses and in England for their own account and for the account of

list.item: To undertake every kind of financial and commercial operation, including advances

cell.p: on Stock Exchange securities and upon cotton and co-ton seed and other merchandise, carrying
over securities, arbitrations, discount and other commission business.
The arrangements made for the formation and promotion of the Company are embodied in
preliminary agreement dated 22nd December 1906 and made between Moise Tilche Fils, B.
Agaion Fils. 8. Tilche & Figii, Clement Castro, Constantin Pringo, Kamel Bey Teymur and
V. Levi & Co. The subscribers to this agreement have agreed to subscribe and underwrite the
whole of the issue of sharer to the public constituting one third of the total issue. The remaining
two-thirds of the issue will be taken up by the subscribers to the agreement in the proportions
shown below, and 1850 of the Deferred Shared will be allotted to them, also shown below, both
Ordinary and Deferred Shares being subscribed tor wholly in cash :

div.p: The firm of V. Levi and Co., in consideration of their transferring the goodwill of their business to the Company, will under the above agreement have the right to take up 2,000 of the Deferred Shares on paying for them in cash The remaining 750 D ferred shares will be allotted equally amongst the five Director, who will pay for them in cash.

The above agreement also contemplates the appointment of M. Victor Levi as Managing Director (Administrateur delegue, of the Company, on a salary of £1000 per annum and a commission of 3 1/2 % on the net profits before any division thereof; and also the appointment of Mr. Neno Levi Mortera as Manager (Directeur) on a salary of £1000 per annum and a commission of 1 1/2 % on the same profits. These appointments will hold good for 5 years.

The Directors are interested in the promotion of the Company to the extent set ont above and as shown in the agreement above referred to, which contains all the arrange­ments made in contemplation of the formation of the Company.

The provisions of the Memorandum and Articles of Association with regard to the position of the shareholders, the division of profits, the creation of a Reserve Fund, and the remuneration of the Directors, are as follows —

From and out of the profits which in respect of each year shall, after deduction of any share attributed to the Managing Director or Manager of the Company, be available for dividens, a sum equal to 10% of such profits shall be carried to a special Reserve Funds; the remaining 90 % of such profits shall be dealt with as follows:—

list.item: The holders of the Ordinary Shares will take fixed preferential Dividend not exceeding the rate of 6 % p.a. o i the Capital lor the time being paid up or cre­dited as being paid up thereon respectively, such Dividend to be paid as regards each year out of the profits of such year and to be non-cumulative.

Of tbe surplus profits remaining after payment of this fixed preferential dividend, 7 % will be allotted to the Board of Directors, as remuneration for their services, such remuneration to be divided among tbe Directors in such proportion and manner as they themselves may determine, and in default of such determination then amongst them equally.

The balance remaining of the surplus profits after providing for the above mentioned Reserve Fund, Preferential Dividend and remuneration of the Directors, shall be divided as to 60% among the holders of the Ordinary Shares rateably and in proportion to the number of Ordinary Shares held by them respectively, and as

div.p: to 40% among the holders of the Deferred Shared rateably and in proportion to the
number of shares held by them respectively.
The holders of the Ordinary Shares are entitled to priority as to return of capital and payment of dividend, whether declared or not, up to the commencement of the winding up.
In addition to the aforesaid remuneration, each Director shall also receive such further sum (if any) as the Company, in General Meeting may from time to time determine.

Any Director may be employed by or hold office of profit under the Company except that of Auditor of the Company, and may sot either personally or as a member of the firm for, or render any professional service to the Company, and may receive remuneration from the Company for so doing in addition to any remuneration payable to him as a Director. If any Director, being willing, shall be called upon to perform extra services or to make any special exertions in going or residing abroad, or in negotiating or carrying into effect any contract or arrangement by the Company or otherwise for any of the purposes of the Company, or to act as trustee for the Company or its debenture holders, and shall do so, the Company may remunerate such Director either by a fixed sum or percentage of profits or otherwise, as may' be determined by the Directors, and such remuneration may be either in addition to, or in substitution for bis remuneration above provided. If any Director shall be appointed to represent the Company as a Director of any subsidiary or other company in which the Company shall he interested, he shall, unless otherwise agreed, be entitled to retain the remuneration attaching to such Directorship for his own muse.
The qualification of a director is the holding of 500 ordinary shares. The Company in General Meeting may increase or reduce the number of Directors.
No promotion money will be paid.

The preliminary expenses of and incidental to the formation of the Company down to end including allotment, including registration fees and stamp duty, legal expenses the scat of advertising and issuing this prospectus but excluding stamp duty on share warrants, will be paid by the Company, and are estimated at £3,000.
Application for shares should be made on the accompanying form and forwarded with cheque for the amount payable on application to the Company’s bankers, the Cassa di

cell.p: The Directors of the Egyptian Salt and Soda Company, Ltd , have decided to issue at par 50,000 new ordinary shares of £1 (one pound sterling) each to rank pari passa with existing ordinary shares. The new shares are now offered by preference to Holders of the 450,000 existing ordinary shares, and will be allotted to applicants in the proportion of one new share for every complete nine old shares. Forms of application can be obtained from the Com­pany's Bankers, the National Bank of Egypt, in Cairo, Alexandria or London.

Holders of share warrants to bearer wishing to exercise their right to subscribe must present their warrants to the Company’s Bankers for , verification and stamping from the 18th to 20th February 1907 together with applications for the new shares and the sum of 10/ (ten shil­lings) per share applied for. The balance of 10/- (ten shillings) per share most be paid on or before 20th March 1907. Share Warrants to bearer will be issued to Allottees in respect of tally-paid shares upon application, and payment of stamp duties.
Registered Share Holders should make appli­cation direct to the Secretary at the Registered Office of the Company, 6 Old Jewry, London, EC.

The Iron-Arsenic Springs, with baths, of " Val Sinestra,” situated near Vulpera, are especially beneficial in cases of nervousness, anæmia and rheumatism.

cell.p: Le taux de l'escompte libre A Londres se maintient à 4 3/4 pour cent. Au Stock Exchan­ge, le Consolidé anglais a rétrogradé hier de 1/8 A a7. L’Unifiée est restée invariée A 102 3/4. La National Bank a perdu 1/8 A 28 1/4. L’A­gricole est demeurée inchagee A 10, de même que la Daira A 17 1/2. La Delta Light a gagné 1/8 A 11 7/8
À Paris, le Crédit Foncier Egyptien et la Banque d'Athenes ont cloture a leurs prix precedents, soit 775 et 135. Les Lots turcs ont avancé de 3 francs A 155.

Ici, la séance de ce matin a été plutôt calme mais la tenue générale du marché a été in­contestablement meilleure qu’hier. Eu outre, la côture a été marquée par de l'anima­tion et de la fermeté, ce qui est d’un bon augure et fait espérer une reprise. Aussi est-il regrettable qu’on nous réserve, pour la semaine prochaine encore, une série d’é­missions dont les effets pourraient bien entraver tontes les bonnes dispositions pos­sibles. On ne saurait vraiment trop engager les promoteurs de nouvelles entreprises A mo­dérer leur ardeur, A endiguer le flot impétu­eux de leurs appels de fonds, de facon A ne nuire ni aux antres, ni surtout A eux-mêmes. Certes, le soleil luit pour tout le monde et il y a de la place pour tous; mais encore est-il prudent da ne pas bourrer A outrance le mar-che égyptien, qui souffre deja visiblement d’une indigestion de titres don l’écoulement semble requérir des drastiques violents. * Fes­tin» lente.” On ne perd rien pour attendre, surtout lorsqu’il s’agit de bonnes affaires; l’es­sentiel est de les espacer et de les produire à des moments opportuns et favorables.

Dans le compartiment des Banques, la Na­tional a clôturé A son prix précédent, soit 28 1/16-1/8, de même que l’Agricole A 9 7/8. Les parts de fondateur du Comptoir Financier, fractionnées en dix Ames, ont été traitées A £ 9.

Le Crédit Fonder a rétrogradé A .721 et son obligation A lots 1886 A 343.La D.ira est restée immobile A 17 6/16-3/8. L’Agrioole du Nil est remontée A 255: par contre, sa part a faibli A 7 5/16. La Nile Land est revenue A 22 5/8 et le Wardan A 7 1/2-9/16. L’Union Foncière s’est tassée A 6 1/4.. L’Allotment s’est encore alour­di A 3 1/4-5/16; sa part a cloture a 125.

Les Entreprises Immobilères et Travaux ont regagné une livre A 10; en bonne demande, leur part a avancé A P.E. 225. L’Epargne Im­mobilière a été ramenée A 3 1/8; sa part a terminé A* 2 2, après avoir fléchi A 190; ce sont la des cours transitoires appelés assurément a attirer l’attention des acheteurs.

L’Express Nile a été l’objet de fluctuations qui l’ont portée de 6 1/4 A 6 5/8 eu attendant mieux par suite des gros avantages offerts par la nouvelle émission fixée au 20 da courant; sa part a avancé A 330. L’Anglo-American Nile

list.item: fléchi A 5 3/8-7/16, les Ciments A 53 et' la Brasserie des Pyramides à 126.

cell.p: Dans le groupe des valeurs hôtelières, les Nungovich ont haussé jusqu’A 30 1/8 pour terminer A 29 3/4. Les Upper Egypt ont avancé A 4 13/16-7/8.
Parmi les petites valeurs, la Delta Land s'est raffermie A 4 1/4. Les Markets sont remontés a 30 sh.

Dana la séance qu’elle a tenue hier soir l’as­semblée générale da la Corporation des Agents de change du Caire a continué de s'occuper des modifications très importantes proposées dans les statuts de la Corporation.

L’assemblée a passé ensuite A l’élection du nouveau Comité. M.M. H. Boutigny, E.C. Hogg, D. K. Raid et Henri de Vries ont déclaré formellement, qu’ils déliraient ne pas faire partie du nouveau Comité et ont, par consé­quent, prié les membres de ne pas porter leurs voix ear leurs noms.
Après quoi, l’assemblée a procédé A l’élec­tion da nouveau Comité, dont on trouvera la composition dans les journaux.

La Conseil d’administration de la Delta Land and Investment Co. a tenu aujourd’hui une réunion pour approuver les résolutions prises par le Board de la Delta Light Railways Co., relatives A la composition du Board local de la première de ces deux Sociétés et A diverses autres questions.

Nous croyons savoir que MM. P. Carver, Maurice Cattani Bey et le capitaine Adams ont été nommés en remplacement des adminis­trateurs de Londres, qui se sont décidés A se retirer. Ces Messieurs formeront le conseil de la Delta Land avec le baron Jacques de Menasce et M. J. W. Williamson. Un membre de la maison Suares leur sera adjoint dès que certaines négociations en cours entre cette maison et la Société auront définitivement abouti.

On annonce (officieusement dans les journaux qu'une assemblée générale extraordinaire de la George Nungovich Hotels sera convoquee poor le 4 mars prochain afin de ratifier la vente du Savoy Hotel et de donner éventuelle­ment les pouvoirs nécessaires au conseil d’ad­ministration pour vendre le Grand Continental
ou tons autres immeubles de la société.

Les actionnaires de la North Egypt Land Co. n’apprendront pas sans intérêt qu’aux termes d’an avis en date du 11 Février courant, putlié avant hier et hier par les jour­naux da Caire et d Alexandrie, le conseil d’ad­ministration de cette Sociéte a décidé que,

tons les appels de fonds précédents doivent être payés avant le 20 Février 1907 et que si l’on manque aa paiement avant la dite date, tontes les actions qui ne seront ainsi immé­diatement payées seront confisquées.

(A similar right is given by this Prospectus to applicants for multiples of • 25 Ordinary Shares)

7,500 Founders’ Share are reserved for subscription by the Directors and their friends, who have arranged for the subscription of the whole of the Capital of the Company The Memorandum and Articles of Association provide that the profits of the Company which it shall from time to time be determined to distribute in respect of any year or other period, shall be applied in order of priority and manner following, that is to say :—

FIRST, as to 5 percent, thereof to payment into the Company’s reserve fund. Secondly, to the payment of a dividend at the rate of 6 per cent, per annum on the capital for the time being paid up on the Ordinary Shares.
Thirdly, 10 per cent, of the residue of such profits shall be paid to the Directors, as,

and that in the winding up of the Company the surplus assets which may be distributable among the Members, shall as to 60 per cent, thereof be divided amongst the holders of the Ordinary Shares, and as to the remaining 40 per cent, thereof, among the holders of the Founders’ Shares.

Egyptian and other companies either on its own account or for others, and to carry on a general financial and trust business for investment of capital in Egypt and the Sudan.

The Directors have been connected with Egypt for many years, and they are confident that there ’an immense field available for remunerative trade and industry They look for a considerable expansion of business relationships between Egypt and other countries, and having regard to the time and political situation and the period of prosperity through which Egypt is passing, they are of opinion that the present is propitious, and they anticipate a successful and remunerative career for this Company, and they have great reliance in the personality of the Manager, who is well known and esteemed in financial circles and whose business relationship and experience is sufficient to warrant a firm and intelligent management.

The Directors and their friends thoroughly believe in the future prosperity of the Company, and accordingly have arranged to themselves subscribe for 81,300 Ordinary Shares, and to take up the whole of this issue without commission.
The Articles of Association provide as follows :
The qualification of every Director shall be the holding of Shares or Share Warrants to Bearer of the Company of the nominal value of not less than £1,000.

That each of the Directors, other than the Chairman, shall be paid out of the funds of the Company by way of remuneration for his services, a salary at the rate of £100 per annum, and the Chairman shall be paid a salary at the rate of £200 per annum. The Directors shall also be entitled to the share of the profits under Clause 6 of the Memorandum of Association (mentioned on the first page of this Prospectus), and the same shall be divided among the Directors in such proportions and manner as they by agreement may determine, and in default of such Agreement equally.

If any Director, being willing, shall be called upon to or shall perform any extra services, or shall make any special exertions in going or resiling out of the country where he usually resides or otherwise, or any of the purposes of the Company, the Company shall remunerate the Director either a fixed sum or by percentage of profits or otherwise as may be determined by the Directors, and such remuneration may be either in addition to, or in substitution for his share in the remuneration above provided.

The Directors may from time to time appoint one or more of their body to be Managing Director or Managing Directors of the Company, either for a fixed term or without any limitation as to the period for which he or they is or are to hold office, and may, from time to time, remove or dismiss him or them from office, and appoint another or others in his or their place or places. The remuneration of a Managing Director shall from time to time be fixed by the Directors or by the Company in General Meeting, and may be by way of salary or commission or participation in profits, or by any or all of those modes.

The estimated amount of the preliminary expenses connected with and incidental to the formation of the Company and the issue of this Prospectus, including Solicitors’ charges, registration fees, advertising, printing, postages, office expenses, etc., is £4000.
A copy of the Memorandum of Association, with the names, addressee and descriptions of the signatories thereto, is printed in the fold, and forms part of this Prospectus.
